case_vignette: A 20-year-old college student comes to the physician because she has been extremely sad for the past 3 weeks and has to cry constantly. Three weeks ago, her boyfriend left her after they were together for 4 years. She has no appetite and has had a 2.3-kg (5.1-lb) weight loss. She has missed several classes because she could not stop crying or get out of bed. She thinks about her ex-boyfriend all the time. She says that she experienced similar symptoms for about 2 months after previous relationships ended. The patient is 158 cm (5 ft 2 in) tall and weighs 45 kg (100 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. On mental status examination she appears sad and cries easily.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.

I've been extremely sad for the past 3 weeks and I can't stop crying.
How old are you?
I'm 20 years old.
Have you experienced any changes in appetite or weight recently?
Yes, I have no appetite and I've lost about 2.3 kilograms.

Okay, thank you for the information. Is there any family history of depression or other mental health disorders that you're aware of?
The case vignette doesn't provide any information about my family history of mental health disorders.
Understood. Have you had any previous episodes of depression or mental health concerns?
Yes, I experienced similar symptoms for about 2 months after previous relationships ended.
Thank you for sharing. Are you currently taking any medications or have you taken any medications in the past for mental health concerns?
The case vignette does not mention me taking any medications for mental health concerns.

Understood. Based on the information provided, it sounds like you may be experiencing a major depressive episode.

**Final Diagnosis:** Major Depressive Disorder
